sentence.text: Patient 1 was 27 years old when first evaluated in medical genetics clinic.
He had received a clinical diagnosis of Crouzon syndrome in childhood at a craniofacial clinic.
Sagittal synostosis was treated with cranioplasty at age 2.5 years.
Postoperatively, the craniofacial shape was described as a tall forehead with frontal bossing and further surgical treatment included fronto-orbital advancement.
There was no documentation of other cranial suture synostosis.
The craniofacial phenotype evolved and at age 7 years he was reported to have brachycephaly with significant vertical and horizontal maxillary hypoplasia and retrusion (Class III malocclusion).
Inner canthal and interpupillary distances were normal at age 7 years.
Serial photographs show progressive midface hypoplasia and retrusion, prognathism and down slanting palpebral fissures (Figure 1).
No primary dental records are available.
The family reports that he had delayed shedding of multiple primary teeth which were then extracted at age 11 years to allow eruption of secondary dentition and facilitate orthodontic treatment.
He had crowding of teeth in the maxillary arch but not mandibular arch.
Normal hearing was documented at age 16 years.
He was treated with orthodontics and LeFort I maxillary osteotomy advancement with iliac crest bone graft and rhinoplasty.
At time of examination, height was 169.5 cm and weight 57.2 kg.
Occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) was 52.4 cm (Z = −3.72) with mild brachycephaly.
There was no proptosis or ptosis.
There were shallow depressions in the lateral forehead above the orbits bilaterally.
There was no significant prognathism.
Hands and thumbs were normal.
The halluces were mildly broad at the proximal interphalangeal joint with mild lateral deviation.
Intelligence is normal.
The remainder of his examination was unremarkable.
